description:
What can I say? This ice-cream is delicious,xxx unique, weird and amazing. I just enjoy seeing how a random blend of "Chopped" basket-like ingredients taste sooooo good as ice cream. Olive Oil ice cream? Yes indeed. Dandelion and chocolate, I guess if you like chocolate ice cream. But basically a lot of what sounds like it tastes strange turns out to be delicious, while other flavor combos maybe miss the mark. The nice thing is that you can try any and all flavors without feeling rushed or guilty or feeling the heat of disapproving looks as you take your time. 
Salt n Straw, a small chain, tends to have a crowd inside and out, and the lines moves steadily enough at all the locations I've tried: Portland, Seattle, and now, San Francisco. 
The ice-cream quality is very nice: creamy, smooth, and full of flavor. It's always a fun and satisfying time here.
author: Ruby H.

description:
Absolute heaven. Im a sucker for crazy flavors and not only are Salt and Straw's wild and on a monthly rotation, the high quality ingredients are hard to beat. I try to go once a month since once their gone, I know I'd regret never having them. Favorites though from the regulars are their malted cookie dough, lavender honey, and olive oil. 
For the cookie dough, malted is the key word- almost caramelized brown sugar with a touch of saltiness is a melt-in-your-mouth  and chunky delight.
The lavender honey taste like fresh, perfectly balanced lavender honey. It's a simple combination that they got just right.
And last but not least, olive oil. The creamiest ice cream ever. Olive oil, especially when you find a good one like they did, should be added to ice cream. Period.
author: Sophia C.

description:
Very interesting flavors. Finally made it to try it out. I got the Peach and Vanilla Cobbler(?) ice cream? The first thing I loved, is they give SOOO much for $5 vs. ahem, other ice cream places which give golfball sized scoops for the same price.

I like the boldness and creativity of this place, but for some reason, after a couple of bites of ice cream, the flavors were too overwhelming and I didn't feel like finishing it (I know, the horror). But I guess if you like bold and wild flavors in your ice cream with every bite, come here. 

Imma stick to Bi-Rite.
author: Hanna M.

description:
So, I work in Anaheim and there's a Salt & Straw opening in the Downtown Disney District. I definitely wanted to drop buy a S&S here in SF to see what this hype was about before it opened in Anaheim, so I planned this little evening for a little taste test. Being a tourist to SF on this visit, I jumped on the local bus line, dropping me off no more than a block away!

It's a quaint little store. Loved the fact that they are using steel spoons for sampling, instead of plastic. So that's a plus! The had buckets on the counter for the used spoons, or you could deposit your spoon in the built in spoon slide (just a chute that collects the spoons, lol). They had such a large variety, I almost tried them all! I think the one that stood out for me, although I wasn't sold on it, was the bone marrow and smoked cherry. It was an interesting flavor, but it didn't fancy my palate as I would have liked it to. So, I ended up with the sea salt with caramel ribbons and east bay rocky road. Both great flavors.

Seating is very limited inside the store. If I recall correctly, there's probably comfortable seating for about 10 people. But it's an ice cream shop, who needs to sit in the shop to eat their ice cream? The location of this store opens the opportunity to walk around. There's a great little park down the street I walked to where I enjoyed my ice cream and people watched.
author: Antonio L.

description:
So glad they opened up in San Francisco. They have an excellent collection of icecream flavors - classics and an entire new seasonal menu for fall / Halloween. And obviously there was a line, which moved pretty quickly. 

Tried the Honey lavender, mt. Tam cheese and and acme bread, gooey chocolate brownie and the strawberry tres leches.  All of them were amazing! My husband and I couldn't agree on our favorite flavor which is such a great problem to have.. Will be back for more.
author: Eshita S.

description:
I've had Salt and Straw three times so I think that definitely warrants a review.  Once was last year a few days before they opened their Fillmore Street location; they had a pop up under the Dome at Westfield and were selling small cups of their ice cream for $5.  I went with the strawberry tres leches which had a nice fresh and creamy strawberry taste.  It started getting a bit too sweet after several bites however.  

I took a trip to their Hayes Street location in June and tried several flavors but none of them really tickled my tastebuds, including their Dandelion chocolate cookies & cream, so I went back to the strawberry tres leches.  On my third time last month, I first sampled two of their specials for the month - a melon and proscuitto and a carrot cake with roasted hazelnut.  The melon and prosciutto was a perfect mix of salty and sweet.  It was refreshing but lacked boldness, dare I say it was very faint.  Next I tried the carrot cake and hazelnut.  This one was a winner!  Is carrot cake healthy?  Lol I guess it's healthier than other cakes but anyways it reminded me of a traditional carrot cake done right - flavorful but not over spiced and without the over sweet cream cheese frosting.  The roasted hazelnuts were a nice touch.  

What I like about Salt & Straw is that they have a broad flavor range for the traditionalists to the adventurists. I also like how Salt & Straw uses local vendors' products in some of their flavors such as Dandelion Chocolate, Mount Tam cheese.  But note that Humphrey Slocombe has done some untraditional flavors (they were the first in the area to have pork flavored ice cream).  In terms of taste I still think that Bi-Rites flavors taste a lot better, are more attractive and aren't as painfully sweet.  Bi-Rite also gives bigger scoops at a better price point and they have a punch card reward system!

I'd still go to Salt and Straw if the ice cream craving hits and I was around one of their locations but I wouldn't go out of my way for them.  Suggestions - Bolder flavors with a little less sugar, be a bit more generous with the scoops or at the very least offer a reward system.
author: Cat C.

description:
They have some pretty awesome ice cream flavors here! There are the oddball flavors (Mt. Tam Cheese, Olive Oil, there was a halloween one made of blood), as well as more standard flavors like Honey Lavender and Tres Leches Strawberry.

I ended up getting the Fudge Brownie ice cream and it was pretty good. Some parts of the ice cream were a bit icy, which was disappointing, but overall the ice cream was really good. The brownies had a rich chocolatey and chewy taste, the ice cream itself was rich in flavor and texture, and overall everything was quite nice!

Great choice, and I'd be back some time to try more of their more interesting flavors.
author: Tyler T.

description:
Probably my favorite ice cream spot in SF - among the many.

Salt & Straw has very interesting flavors that may not sound great at first, but they somehow make it work! You can try unlimited samples (they don't make you feel bad even asking for 5!) until you figure out the best one for you.

I love that their ice cream is incredibly creamy and rich. The scoop is a healthy serving too.

There's almost always a line, but don't let that deter you. It's worth it.
author: Sally L.

description:
A friend and I were walking around Hayes Valley when we bumped into Salt & Straw. Decided to walk in on Saturday, September 8th around 11pm. Even though it was late, there was still a line. I think it took a little over 15 mins to order.

I believe I tried the Strawberry Tres Leches, Old Potrero Rye & Cocoa Nib Sorbet, and Freckled Mint TCHO-colate Chip. I ultimately picked a single scoop of Matcha & Black Raspberry on a waffle cone. (From my pic of the menu, the scoop was $5 and the cone was $1.25, so my dessert was $6.25.) The ice cream was rich and creamy with a nice balance of flavors. The berry added a bit of texture and a subtle sweet tartness to the matcha. Definitely my kind of scoop as I adore green tea and fruit.

I first tried Salt & Straw in Portland, so I'm glad they've made their way to SF. Worth checking out if you're an ice cream lover.
author: Elena N.

description:
Salt & Straw is THE best ice cream shop in SF. It's so good - last week I came here three separate times in a 24 hour period. 

My top two flavors are the peach & vanilla bean crumble and the hey boo coconut jam & rice crispy treat, both on the seasonal menu. They do unlimited samples, so try a bunch. 

They also offer specials sometimes - most recently it was $1 off a double scoop - so be sure to ask about what they have going on!
author: Sarah B.

description:
Note to self: NEVER get the cone again. D: 

I swear, as soon as I walked out the shop, the ice cream started dripping and leaking everywhere. I usually prefer walking with my ice cream but I had to actually sit on one of the benches for a min because it was such a mess lol. 

Normally I'd dock a star but luckily for S&S their ice cream is so damn good that I just can't bring myself to do it lol. Like all my S&S experiences, the service was super warm and friendly. Let me sample the flavors I wanted to try. This time I went with one of their Halloween flavors, the great candycopia, which was so amazing that I'm already making plans to go back at the end of the month just to get a pint. Also got the salted, malted cookie dough, also really good. 

If Salt and Straw ever opens a shop in the East Bay, WHEW!...Me and my wallet are in trouble D: lol.
author: Brianna B.

description:
Quick (and embarrassing) story: I said "this ice-cream is so good" so many times that my dad told me to shut up. 

I am glad I reached out to some San Fran foodies for food recommendations. I was here on vacation and as noted by many of my friends, the West Coast has some of the most innovative foods. My experience at Salt & Straw is and will be unforgettable (I apologize in advance if this sounds a bit much). 

The reasons are as follows: 
1) Flavour - I came during their vegetables-infused series and got Beet Red Velvet and Carrot Cake Batter and Pralines Hazelnuts. I also got two flavours off of their classic menu - Organic Roots Arbquina Olive Oil and Breakaway Matcha and Black Raspberry. I recall watching hours of baking competitions and one common critique amongst the judges would be the absence of a stated flavour. At Salt & Straw, I was able to taste every flavour that was listed. 

2) Size - If you don't have a bottomless pit like me, you might have difficulty finishing these. Though I originally got these to share among 4 people, I ended up loving the ice-cream so much and devoured all of them. 

3) Locally sourced - MAY be sustainable in some aspects but... warning: I'm an advocate for sustainability and ethics - not sure to what magnitude this helps out the local economy...

But politics aside - this is one of the greatest ice-cream shops I've ever been to!
author: Sharon T.

description:
Who doesn't love ice cream? Let me remind you that I'm allergic to milk - especially heavy cream which is used to make ice cream - and I still frequent ice cream shops. I just try to stick to the vegan/sorbet options. And I really love Salt & Straw because they let you taste everything, in fact they insist you try more when you only give them a few flavors to try, so I always sample more. Sure, I might get a little stomach ache for those little tasters, but that's not their fault!! They have so many options to choose from and their ice cream flavors are very specific to the neighborhood and city they reside in, which I appreciate. Nowhere else will you find a Mt Tam Cheese with Toasted Acme Bread flavor (and yes, it tastes exactly like Toast and Cheese). 

After trying 5-6 flavors, many of them being vegan, I ordered the Dandelion Chocolate Hazelnut Cookies and Cream (v/gf) + the Carrot Came Batter and they were great. Single scoops are unfortunately $5 which is a lot of money for a single scoop of ice cream BUT if you get the split for .50 cents more, you get to order 2 flavors and essentially get 2 single scoops for $5.50. Definitely recommend doing that.

Be prepared to wait in line regardless of what time of day you show up! It moves relatively quickly though so just be patient.
author: Bri T.

description:
So happy they decided to come further west, from Portland! Ever since I fell in love with the S&S out there (1 scoop is like 2 scoops!), I was ecstatic to learn that they came to SF. The flavors are original to SF, and constantly changing. We got the Sightglass coffee with cashew bits. Everything was mixed very well together, and was super creamy. This ice cream is definitely on the heavier side, and reminds me of a glorified Coldstone, given how unique the flavors are and the mix of crunchy and creamy. The line gets very long! So try to come here during dinner or lunch time (dessert before the meal amirite).

YOMMY!!!
author: Vickie Z.

description: Our third location! My husband love it here! We skipped out on dessert at our dinner to come here. This location has a spacious interior although not much place to sit to enjoy your ice cream. Many flavors to choose from and for the most party pretty delicious. I do like that you get a good amount per scope. We go to Salt & Straw a lot and will probably be returning. Service is pretty good too.
author: Sarah C.

description:
3.5/5 
This place has been on my list for a while and glad I finally got to try it. There's usually a line, but it goes by fairly quickly. You can sample the flavors which I sampled quite a few of them and only enjoyed one flavor. Honey lavender! You can get in cup or cone and I opted for the waffle cone which made it even better!

This place has tons of different flavors but out of the 7 I tried - I think they were all toooo sweet (except the honey lavender). Sample before you chose :)
author: Christine N.

description:
da best cream in da city. 

Often a line, but it'll be worth it. Try all the flavors. Sugar cone is free (waffle cone is a charge). Always great service.
author: Kelly G.

description: Love that this place opened up in San Francisco. I stood in a long line but it was very much worth the wait  !
author: Prerna L.

description:
Game changer.
This place has become one of my favorite ice cream shops.

Why?
1. Creamy but not overly buttery where it'll hurt my stomach. It has a nice consistency of ice and cream. So, it doesn't melt as fast in my opinion.

2. Flavor. The flavors are unique. They have seasonal/limited flavors and the basic favors. Both are such a treat because they taste good! I've sampled and had different flavors but my favorite so far are salted caramel ribbon, strawberry tres les, and Tokyo pb&j

3. Sweetness. Just the right level of sweetness that you don't get sick or full too fast. Because it's not too sweet, I can finish it all! I leave no ice cream behind.

And, they make their waffle cones in house so one more reason why I like this place. I get to have delicious ice cream with in house waffle cone! Thumbs up!
author: Ngoc P.

description:
Dylan is the bestest ice cream server I've ever met. Talk about superb customer service.

My friend and I had swung by on a hot Friday afternoon in June to satiate our sweet teeth. As I've mentioned in my other Salt & Straw review, the best way to get 4 scoops for less than $10 is to order a double scoop (2 full scoops for $7) and split scoop it (turns those 2 full scoops into 4 kid scoops for an extra $0.50 per full scoop). $8 for four amazing flavors, and Dylan knew exactly what I was looking for.

Salt & Straw was featuring a Guest Chef Collaboration Series in June with limited edition flavors from 5 famed chefs. Dylan was kind enough to give us generous samples of each flavor, so much so that we almost didn't have enough room for our actual paid ice cream! He also eloquently broke down the flavor dimension in a manner worthy of Michelin-starred restaurant menus. The flavors themselves were as complex as their descriptions, and, honestly, my palate was too overwhelmed to enjoy any of the limited edition flavors.

-Duck crackling with cherry preserves: very salty (due to the crackling) and rich (due to the duck fat).
-Tokyo PB&J: tastes crazy similar to Shelly Senbei rice crackers, but a bit too sweet.
-Ras el hanout (spice mix) and pickled rose petal jam: too many conflicting flavors.
-Roasted beets and Humboldt fog: very smoky.
-Jeweled brown butter rice gelato: I can't remember why I wasn't a fan of this one.

We then sampled a bunch of classic flavors, and I decided on Sightglass Coffee & Single Origin Dandelion Chocolate with its subtle bitter notes to offset the silky sweetness from Roasted Strawberry Coconut. My friend opted for the Salted Malted Chocolate Chip Cookie Dough (love those dough bits) and the Tokyo PB&J from the featured flavors. Dylan then proceeded to pile four generous scoops on top of each other, to the amazement of guests around us. We topped off our tower with a complimentary sugar cone and walked out the door ready to brave the summer heat.

They rotate featured flavors every month--per their website, it looks like berries are their theme for July (and how appropriately so!). And if those themed flavors don't float your boat, their tried & true classics will always be there.
author: Adele F.

description: So let's get one thing straight right now, the quality of this ice cream is off the hook!  It's mega creamy and super vibrant flavors. I love the themed stuff they do like the flavor with pigs blood in it for the month of October or the one with the chocolate covered crickets. Also the fact that you can try all of that without having to commit is great. But here's my one major gripe with salt & straw along with all the other places like this that are emerging. Where are the normal flavors?  We get it, you guys are super creative and can make ice cream out of cold pressed hay juice. But when my 4 year old can't find one single ice cream flavor she's comfortable with then maybe we need to dial back the Strawberry Tres Leches flavor to just Strawberry.
author: Marcus K.

description:
Okay, I can see why Salt & Straw is so popular.  They have really unique flavors and some that are local to the city they're located in!

I tried the Sightglass Coffee & Single Origin Dandelion Chocolate, Berkeley Olive Grove Olive Oil, Duck Crackling with Cherry Preserves, and Honey Lavender as samples on my first visit.  Our scooper recommended getting the Sightglass coffee with the Olive Oil, and after trying the samples, we decided to get scoops of those!  The flavors work so well together!  I highly recommend!  Duck crackling was interesting and lavender was very floral.  On a second visit, I also enjoyed the Fresh Sheep's Cheese and Strawberries!  You can really taste the fresh hood strawberries!

It is expensive ($5 for a single scoop, +0.50 to split scoop with two flavors, $7 for a double, $11/pint), but you get a generous amount of high quality handmade ice cream that is so darn good.  They're super friendly and patient with samples as well!  Can't wait to try more flavors!
author: Stephanie Z.

description:
Salt & Straw is the best ice cream in the world. Or at least my favorite. Insanely creamy and decadent yet inventive and unpredictable. Sometimes monthly offerings are full of creative takes on sweet classics and sometimes they're full of bizarre scoops composed of flowers and vegetables and, yup, even BLOOD! Wild. 

This location is slightly smaller than the one on Fillmore but I prefer it as it's a little closer to where I live and generally easier to park. It's also not far from civic center Bart so it's more generally accessible for those commuting that way. 

My go-to high key recommendations for you are Almond Brittle with Salted Ganache, Sea Salt Caramel Ribbons, the SF-exclusive Roasted Strawberry Tres Leches and the Cali-exclusive Salted Malted Chocolate Chip Cookie Dough. Those are the four I would lean on from the permanent  menu but I highly encourage trying whatever seasonal scoops are available as well!

Also, bonus side note, the employees here are amazing. Elly, Xander, and Sean stand out as truly passionate masters of their craft.
author: Sean S.

description:
It's about time! I've been wanting to visit Salt & Straw since it opened (or check out the location in Portland) but never made the time. Finally after a group dinner down the street at Monsieur Benjamin, a few of us decided to stand in line for some of the most amazing and memorable ice cream we'll ever eat.

Meanwhile, my fiancé kept saying we should go to Smitten instead, but I wanted to try something new. I love that S&S has tons of unique flavors. Though you'll likely find yourself waiting in line, it buys you time to go back and forth between the two flavors you want. I'll solve your dilemma... just get both.

For me, it was all about the carrot cake, which was on the list of special flavors. I love carrot cake, and thinking about that in the form of ice cream was heavenly. I got a single, large scoop of it, and I appreciated the texture of the mix-ins, reminiscent of actual carrot cake. Oh and they have vegan options for those who can't consume dairy.

I hope S&S stays open for awhile. There's so many great eateries and bars in Hayes Valley. I'm sure they get enough customers on a daily basis. Since my favorite ice cream shop in the Tenderloin closed, I'm in the market for a new one. This one is high on the list, but I'll only be able to tell after visiting a few more times.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
Heard this place was a fantastic place for ice cream so I definitely had to drop by. 

What really caught me off guard was that they had so many unique flavors. So the first thing on my mind was to try to avoid the traditional flavors. It was about 8-9 at night and it was fairly packed with the line reaching up to the door and I would say thats probably a small line! I wouldn't be surprised if it was out the door and down the block some.

The employees were incredibly helpful and was very willing to let sample a decent amount of their flavors before deciding on something. I was leaning towards the tasting flight ($11.50) which would have consisted of four kid scoops however the employee gave me a tip to save some money.

Tip: Order a double split scoop which will have four flavors and will be essentially the same amount as the tasting flight but $3 cheaper!

Ended up getting the almond brittle w/ salted ganache, sightglass coffee and single origin dandelion chocolate, honey lavender, and dandelion chocolate's beans to bar s'mores.

The flavors were absolutely delicious with a perfect balance of creamy. The portions weren't too big which was expected since they were kid scoops but will be going back soon to try their other flavors!
author: Timothy D.

description:
Not even a huge ice cream guy, but truly unique flavors and super high quality. Really enjoyed it.

Recommend trying Olive Oil.
author: Alex L.

description:
Tuesday and Thursday mornings at 7:10 am are my favorite times of the week (along with 4 pm on Friday, hello weekend!) because of Star 101.3's Second Date Update. In a recent installment, a lady calls in because her date ghosted on her after their first date. She thought they hit it off because they even held hands. Awwwww...

Sandy and Marcus (the radio hosts) call her date to see why he hasn't contacted her for a second date. 

So...apparently, she arrived drunk to the date. 

While they were walking, he was scared she was going to fall so he held her hand. When they sat down on a bench, she whipped out her vodka bottles from her bag - yes, plural!

Damn, girl...you're a mobile happy hour!

I feel for the guy because I've gone a date with a guy who came blasted to dinner and it was so embarrassing.  

May I suggest a short ice cream date in the afternoon as a first date?

If so, I highly recommend Salt & Straw! 

This location has a lot of cute shops and Patricia Green (park) that you can stroll through afterwards.

San Francisco has tons of great ice cream shops but Salt & Straw is my absolute favorite new skool, hipster ice cream shop. Here's why:

(1) Crazy, unique one of a kind flavors. Each city has their own specialty "classic" flavors like Honey Lavender, Berkeley Olive Grove Olive Oil, Chocolate Gooey Brownie, Roasted Strawberry Tres Leches, etc. AND, each month they roll out a handful of special flavors of the month. 

For June, they have a collab with award winning chefs:
*Duck Crackling with Cherry Preserves with Duck Fat Ice Cream & Honey Gastrique (Chef Traci Des Jardins of Jardiniere, San Francisco)

*Toyko PB&J with Japanese Whiskey-Spiked Strawberry Jam, Peanut Butter & Caramelized White Chocolate Feuilletine (Chef Gabriel Rucker of Le Pigeon, Portland)

*Ras el Hanout & Pickled Rose Petal Jam (Chef Renee Erickson of The Walrus and The Carpenter, Seattle)

*Roasted Beets & Humboldt Fog with Apple-Beet Jam & Candied Walnuts (Chef Brian Malarkey of Herb & Wood, San Diego)

*Jeweled Brown Butter Rice Gelato with Pumpkin Seed Caramel & Verjus-Cured Currants (Chefs Sara Kramer & Sarah Hymanson of Kismet, Los Angeles)

(2) I know some of their flavors sound hella over the top but the combos work! All the flavors I've sampled have a fantastic creamy texture with well-balanced flavors. 

My favorite classic flavors are Double-Fold Vanilla and Peach Vinegar Cobbler (which is not available right now - *cries*).

This time, I tried their June chef collab flavors -  Roasted Beets & Humboldt Fog w/ apple-beet jam & candied walnuts and Duck Cracklings & Cherry Preserves w/ duck fat ice cream & honey gastrique (small split scoop + waffle cone $6.75): https://bit.ly/2kNtOAS.

I love savory sweet combos so my favorite between the two was the roasted beets and goat cheese - refreshing with a nice tangy funk and good crunch from the walnuts. 

If you've had their bone marrow w/ cherry preserves (a special flavor last year), then you will like the duck fat ice cream. It's rich and savory with a light sweetness from the honey. And, the best part is the duck cracklings brittle. Fat = flavor! 

(3) High-quality, locally sourced ingredients. This Portland based company has built relationships with local purveyors and purchase as many locally sourced ingredients (e.g. Sightglass Coffee, Dandelion Chocolate, and Humboldt Fog) as they can to use in their ice cream. 

(4) Fantastic owners and staff. When I visited their Pac Heights location on opening day, the owners, Kim and Tyler took the time to greet EVERY single person standing in line to thank them for coming, explained their flavors, and handed out their favorite sea salt caramels from Portland. They started out as a little hand pushed ice cream cart at a Portland street corner so it's great to see as they expand, how humble and appreciative they are of their customers.  

I've had nothing but positive experiences at their shops. The staff is always friendly and more than happy to provide free samples. Be mindful of the line though.

Sorry, I didn't get his name but the young Asian guy working on Friday, June 1st at 2:15 pm was AWESOME. Super enthusiastic guy who kindly went through all their new chef collab flavors with us. He also took the time to ask if we had food allergies before the sampling began (there was no line at the time).

(5) Giving back to the community. For their special collabs, they give about 50% of profits to charities: https://portlandfoodanddrink.com/salt-straw-walks-talk/. For their June chef collab flavors, the proceeds are going to No Kid Hungry.  

A location in Burlingame and Palo Alto are in the works which is super exciting as I haven't found a good ice cream shop there. 

So, if you're looking for a low commitment first date, head to Salt & Straw (expect long lines on the weekends) but if your date is an alkie...may want to steer clear of the Tokyo PB&J with Japanese whiskey spiked strawberry jam. Just sayin'...
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
I live for ice cream.

I once attempted (and unfortunately failed) the San Francisco Creamery challenge, getting through 3/4 of a gallon of ice cream and a gallon of toppings in 30 minutes. I once ate half a pint of ice cream a day every day for an entire month. My health may be questionable, but my love for ice cream is most certainly not.

My favorite ice cream in the whole wide world will forever be the B3 flavor from Toscanini's in Cambridge, MA.

But Salt & Straw is a very close contender (there's also the slight issue of Cambridge being 3000 miles away at the moment). Sure it's originally a Portland chain and they're bougie af, but the frozen combination of fat, sugar and diabetes in a cup speaks for itself.

They seem quite inventive with their flavors, and it's actually quite cute how they have some wild seasonal flavors. That said, when I come here, I have my eyes on the prize: double scoop of Sea Salt with Caramel Ribbons and Salted, Malted, Chocolate Chip Cookie Dough. They need to work on being less verbose on the naming here, but I am a forgiving man.

I leave happy. And I like to think that the mental health boost from that happiness enables me to live just a tad bit longer...or at least until the next double scoop.
author: Harry X.

description: My favorite go-to for ice cream. Always different flavors to try and the place to go to for dessert after dining at nearby yummies (my fave combo is going to A Mano for brunch, walk and shop around, head to salt & straw, and walk and shop around more with ice cream in hand). I recommend the Strawberry Tres Leches if you like jam and texture. Otherwise go for any coffee flavors for that smooth touch!
author: Theresa Thao N.

description:
As you walk past this place, the smell of cream and sugar wafts through your nostrils and makes you instantly crave ice cream.

Your addiction is then supported by a seasonal menu with flavors that somehow make even the most classic option, like a chocolate chip cookie dough, taste better than any chocolate chip cookie dough ice cream you've ever had. But then, you become even more interested by certain flavors that are specifically local, or unique ones like a matcha blackberry variation (which is the one I chose and loved).

You may be completely confused about what you want, because, well they all tasted so damn good and the line (for once) was kinda short...but that's when you've gotta go all out at try as many as you want on the list to narrow it down. And if you really can't make up your mind, they do have pints you can buy and take to go!

The one thing I didn't like was the extra 50 cent charge for getting multiple scoops. A $5 single scoop is already pretty pricey, but again, it is SF so no surprises there.
author: Allie L.

description:
San Francisco has an abundance of high quality ice cream places. Salt & Straw is top 2 in my opinion (Humphrey Slocombe being the other).  I have indulged at the Hayes Valley location several times now and will continue to do so.

Salt & Straw does wonderful ice cream collaborations with other specialty food purveyors and chefs with special flavors changing with the seasons.  They also have their core, always on the menu flavors.  My favorite flavors are their Sea Salt Caramel Ribbon and their Double Fold Vanilla.  My measuring stick for an ice cream place is how good their vanilla is.  Salt & Straw's vanilla is solid (you can really taste the vanilla beans).

Service is wonderful and very friendly.  Pro tip: go on the weekdays during the day if you don't want to wait in line.
author: Oliver S.

description: One of my all time favorite ice-cream places in SF.  Love the fact that they change the seasonal flavors every month, so there is always something new to try.  Some of the flavors are truly unconventional and creative.  The location in Hayes valley isn't as long as the other location, but parking is an issue.  Typically, my husband just drops me off and then goes somewhere to wait until I get my ice-cream.  My favorite is sightglass coffee.  It has a deep, rich coffee taste.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
I really enjoyed this  salt and straw location. ( they are also in Portland, L.A, San Diego, and Seattle)

We actually stumbled upon it walking around Hayes Valley and had to try it.

Unique flavors (some infused with unique ingredients such as tea leaves etc)). We actually opted for somewhat more traditional flavors. The salted malted milk with cookie dough and sight glass coffee with dandelion chocolate.

We loved the ice cream. Creamy and rich with flavors that were unique but subtle.

The waffle cones are warm and fresh.

Maybe I'm jaded by SF prices but for a rather large serving  in a waffle cone it's pretty good at $6.25

Service here is actually stellar: super friendly and they allow you to try Everything!!!  Loved the tres leches.

If you're in the ice cream mood near Hayes valley go!!!
author: David G.

description:
Unique and surprising. That's how I'd describe the flavors here. If you love ice cream and want to try something more than just your average vanilla and cookie dough, this is the spot. And don't worry, they have some "normal" flavors too!

I tried a bunch because they had a special menu up and they were all funky. Really enjoyed the beet and goat cheese as well as the Tokyo PB&J! I ended up getting a scoop of the chocolate gooey brownie and cookie dough (lame, I know!). 

Tip: they will split a scoop into two flavors, but it will cost you! Scoops are big here!
author: Stephanie K.

description: Best cookie dough ice cream I've ever had.  Definitely worth trying while in town, but other great options as well.
author: Neal K.

description:
Hands down the best ice cream I've ever had. My first experience here was during Thanksgiving last year and like most people, I was very apprehensive about flavors such as Ham and Mashed Potatoes. But somehow S&S nails it every time. I still think about the Sweet Potato Casserole flavor I had that first time. Life changing!

Came here again last night and had another wonderful experience. I love how the employees take their time with letting you try as many flavors as you want. Special shout out to Luigi who gave us just the best experience. We left smiling and with the most delicious Halloween flavored ice cream imaginable.
author: Lauren W.

description:
While nothing holds a candle to the West Bay's own Bi-Rite, a Portland invader by the name of Salt & Straw is sure making waves here.

In addition to a core selection of flavors featuring local vendors like Sightglass Coffee, TCHO chocolate, and Mt. Tam cheese, they also have a seasonally rotating menu. Currently, for example, the theme is berries, with flavors ranging from mildly surprising (fresh sheep's cheese and strawberries) to borderline provocative (goat cheese marionberry habanero). 

Even if there are long lines here, they move reasonably fast, as there are at least half a dozen servers here at any time. And despite the lines, each server takes care to offer personalized service, walking from behind the counter to greet you in person and offer as many tastes as you want. But, please, folks, be considerate of the line, have some ideas in mind as you browse the menu while waiting, and limit those tastings to a reasonable number. 

A solid addition to the Bay Area. Welcome, Portlanders!
author: Vincent L.

description:
Stopped by on a late Thursday night! My boyfriend and I were trying to find Smitten but stumbled upon this place instead.

I was so excited to order, I over did it. They have tons of regular and seasonal flavors to choose from and unlimited amount of samples. They really want you to try their ice cream! The sample spoons are metal (yay for reusable utensils!) and there's a "spoon shoot" by your knees to recycle the used utensils.

I eagerly ordered 2 scoops of the honey lavendar in a waffle cone. I should have asked how big the scoops were before ordering because THEY ARE FRICKIN MASSIVE. I immediately regretted it and asked for a cup on the side to save the second scoop for later. My boyfriend got the salted caramel, which is their OG flavor. And it was bomb. So good. So salty. Absolutely delicious. Our total came out to $15 after tax and tip, and you may be thinking, holy shit that's a lot for ice cream. But keep in mind, the scoops are HUGE, and that cost included 3 scoops and an extra waffle cone ($1.25) making it less than $5 per scoop. I would definitely come back to try their other flavors!!
author: Quynh T.

description:
There's always a long line to order, but it's totally worth it. Way better than Smitten because they have a whole lot more flavors and better options. 

The Strawberry Dulce de Leche is AMAZING, but maybe too sweet...even for me! Next time, I'll ask them if they can do half scoops of flavors.

The Salted Malted Chocolate Chip Cookie Dough is also de-lish. They incorporate huge chunks of cookie dough. 

The staff here is fun and sweet. I'll be returning very soon!
author: Cece Y.

description:
Quality and unique ice cream flavors make Salt & Straw worth a visit or two or three! I've been here a few times, and have been to their locations in LA and Portland even before they opened up in San Francisco, and each time I go, I just fall in love with it more and more. 

Salt & Straw made me love Vegan Ice Cream with its Candied Mango Faux-Yo flavor! I loved how their vegan ice cream had enough body to make it very similar to regular ice cream. The vegan ice creams I've had in the past have been too soft. They melt fast and the texture is definitely not like regular ice cream. The Mango Faux-Yo was nice and tart, and had nice chunks of Candied mango. I got it twice since it was so good! 

I've also had their Strawberry Tres Leches, Peach Vinegar Cobbler, Lemon Meringue Pie, and Salted Malted Chocolate Cookie Dough. We once ordered a tasting flight of their ice cream, so we could taste different flavors. It's a good way to experiment with new flavors as well as enjoy your favorite flavors. 

We will definitely be back. I don't eat much sweet stuff anymore, maybe once or twice a month (unless I'm on vacay or traveling). I'll save my allowance for sweets for Salt & Straw's ice creams!
author: Hazel C.

description: If you haven't been to Salt & Straw yet, please correct your error! This is the most thoughtful and inspiring ice cream shop. I've never been turned off by a specialty flavor (except maybe the rye sorbet, but whiskey isn't a personal preference) and the staff allow you to try every single one. Every time you go, someone takes care of you, quite literally answering any questions you have, explaining the concept and technique behind any flavor you're curious about, to make sure you leave both informed and satisfied. Loved the Hayes location especially, the customer service has been great everywhere, but it was exceptional here.
author: Lena S.

description:
Pros:
+ Line moves fast
+ Staff members are friendly and knowledgeable
+ Unique and changing flavors
+ Creamier consistency, but not too intolerable (will melt fast)
+ Convenient location in Hayes Valley

Cons:
- N/A

Recommendations:
+ Honey Lavender (not soapy at all!)
+ Chocolate Gooey Brownie
+ Double Fold Vanilla

Parking is problematic here. If you're gonna drive, I'd suggest parking a few blocks out. Nice area to walk around anyway. But take your valuables.
author: Fanny W.

description: Salt n Straw was discovered by us on our recent trip to Portland. We loved it during our trip so we had it twice during our stay. We noticed more opened up closer to home and decided to give it a try. Still delicious! Only thing you have to not get annoyed by snotty city dwellers....you know who you are.
author: Reggie C.

description: Amazing unique flavors! Extremely sad that they no longer have Almond Brittle Salted Ganache :(
author: Sam W.

description:
I've heard so much about Salt and Straw from my friends and coworkers so I decided to check out what the hype was all about. 

I went at 10:35pm on a Saturday night and there was a really long line outside. We ended up waiting 30 minutes to get inside, but realized that each of the servers are personally tending to you and giving you samples. 

We ordered the Sightglass Coffee and the Matcha and Black Raspberry and they were both AMAZING! I've had my fair share of coffee ice creams and this one was really creamy but not overpowering in the authentic coffee flavor, and I was warned that it does have the caffeine content of a cup of coffee! 

Definitely would come back again and try out ALL the unique flavors!!
author: Lydia S.

description:
These lines were out the door when we went on a Saturday evening. We opted to get a pint of ice cream to share instead.

We got a vegan one (no dairy). It was chocolate dandelion with cookies and cream. It wasn't bad, although I could definitely taste the coconut when I had my first bites. I'm actually not a huge fan of the coconut flavor but it was okay the more I ate. The ice cream wasn't overwhelmingly sweet. My four friends and I demolished a pint.

I came back later and tried the brownie one. It's pretty good, very chewy brownie pieces. I thought the birthday cake and berry one was ok. I don't really like fruit in my ice cream though.
author: Danielle C.

description:
4.25 Stars
I have been wanting to try Salt & Straw for over 5 years, but haven't made the pilgrimage before.  Maybe my expectations were just too darn high, but this wasn't the most AMAZING ice cream I have eaten.  It was, however, DELICIOUS ice cream.  Don't get me wrong, I would eat it again and again.  I think it is my fault for expecting this to be mind blowing.

Anyways... I ordered the flight with pot of gold (for my 5 year old, tastes like lucky charms), strawberry tres leches (my favorite), sea salt caramel (yummy), and the seasonal chocolate potato chip cup cake (just okay).  My server was so so so so so nice.  He was wonderful.  He happily gave my son and me about a dozen samples and treated us to a waffle cone.  He was a real sweetheart.  

The ice cream is still very very very good =)
author: Kat M.

description: Of all the ice cream shops in SF, this is by far my favorite. They introduce new flavors all the time and not just 1 or 2 flavors but at least 5 flavors every month it seems and on top of their 13 classic flavors which also changes. So every time I stop by there is a always a new flavor I'm willing to try. Their flavors is unique. I remember Thanksgiving time they had ice cream that tasted like stuffing and it was so good! I like to check their website to see what new flavors they have. Surprisingly, I rarely notice a long line compared to other ice cream shops which makes Salt & Straw my go to ice cream shop. If there is ever a line, I'd skip the line and go straight to their refrigerator and take home a pint ($10) with me. Usually I like to get the flight ($11) which let's me have 4 different flavors to share with my partner or friends. As far as I know, there is no limit on samples!
author: Vinkin Ken T.

description: Yummy Ice cream shop with a lot of unique flavors!! Ordered one of the July specials- Birthday cake and blackberries. Also got the cookie dough flavor. Both were quite good! I hoped there would be more blackberry jam and the birthday cake ice cream would have more flavor. Also had chunks of vanilla cake in it -yum!! still pretty decent. Cookie dough flavor was also very good! Nothing too crazy My bf ordered the cookie dough ice cream and wasn't sure it was worth the wait. Line was out the door Saturday afternoon and did not move very quickly. You can try different flavors when you get to the front of the line- I think that slows the process a bit. Single scoop $5, waffle cone is extra. Definitely stop by if you're in the mood for unique ice cream flavors. July theme is berries!!
author: Amanda C.

description:
First time in SF and our friends recommended this place for ice cream.  We arrived Wed night and there was already a line out the door. Flavors change regularly but there are always a few staple flavors - one of which is honey lavender which is what I got. I only got the kid scoop and coming from Canada, it's the size of a regular scoop of ice cream in my opinion (ie more than enough). However if you'd like to indulge yourself in ice cream the regular scoop is described as the size of a tennis ball. 

I don't think they limit how many samples you can try which is why the line is so long. Take advantage and try all the flavours!!
author: Justina L.

description:
I've had the pleasure of ice cream at this shop several times. If the line is short or long, you can expect friendly and helpful service. Given the popularity (and busy-ness) of this shop. The flavors? You are bound to find something that you'll like and have never tried. I like the idea of tasting flavors I'm curious about, but don't want to commit to a whole scoop of it. 

One thing that stands out about this particular visit, is they had Limited Edition Flavors: Student inventor Series. From what our host said, they had 4th graders invent flavors for Salt and Straw to make ice cream into. The Cookie Monster (which is blue with cookies in it), Spring Flower Cream, Lots a'Nacho, Rose and Lavender Patels, and Mango Tango. I tried the Lots a'Nacho, it was interesting. Not unpleasant, but passed on getting a whole scoop of it. Bravo for making a 4th grader's dream come true. 

Onto what they call Classic Flavors: This trip I "committed" to the Sea Salt with Caramel Ribbons and the Chocolate Gooey Brownie. Excellent. 
This place is worth the visit. Tip: If there is a long line, you can pick up a pint and skip the line. The only trouble with that is you'll need to agree on a flavor on whoever you're with, and you won't have the pleasure of tasting other unusual flavors.
author: Jason P.

description:
Yes, the ice cream quality is as good as good as they all say it is. I was honestly really impressed with the amount of flavor in this ice cream. But I'm getting ahead of myself. 

This story begins with a Powerpoint presentation. My fellow intern and I were supposed to give a presentation to the president and COO, as well as some other random people in the office. What got us through the whole process of preparing for this presentation was the thought that we would go get the flight of ice cream at Salt and Straw after the presentation. 

After surviving the ordeal, we set out on our journey, with another intern in tow. We were on a mission.

Entering the store, I noted the lack of seating. There were some benches outside and a small bar for three people by the window. Besides that, the nearby park was the only other seating. 

We decided to get the flight, which includes four flavors of our choice. It's probably the best deal they offer, as it is $11 for 4 scoops. We spent a good 20 minutes deciding what to order, since it all sounded so good. We decided to go with the Lavender Honey, Sea Salt and Caramel, Mint Chip, and Cookie Dough. We failed to notice all of the special berry flavors they were serving, which was a bit of a blessing since it would have just made it more difficult to choose flavors. 

My favorite was the Sea Salt and Caramel. the balance of flavors was superb. The Cookie Dough didn't really stand out, but it still tasted good. The Lavender Honey had a very strong flavor, which was amazing for those who like lavender. If you don't like floral flavor, stay away from the lavender. The Mint Chip was really good in the classic high quality mint chip was. 

We sat at the bar, each taking turns photographing the aesthetically pleasing bowls of ice cream. It was a bit awkward sitting at the bar because we made eye contact with every singe person who happened to walk by the store. Other than that, the music was quiet so it was easy to chat/rant about the presentation.

We left the shop very satisfied, happy to have had the successful ice cream experience we expected.  

(I took off one star for high prices plus lack of seating)
author: Amara C.

description:
This place is AMAZING! It's like a dream come true for ice cream lovers!

Came on a Sunday afternoon and we waited for about 20 min. They have a lot of non traditional flavors and it was fun to try out the different flavors. My absolute favorite was honey lavender! The two flavors go so well together and it wasn't overly sweet. The servers are very nice and they don't seem to mind if we wanted to try out a couple more flavors. They are also very knowledgable about all the different flavors the store offered. If you cannot make up your mind, you can also order split scoop or a tasting flight so you can have it all. 

If you don't want to wait in line, they also have pints and merchandise available where you can just grab and go.
author: Katie M.

description:
Great ice cream place in Hayes Valley.  The ice cream flavors are on the far end of the extreme scale.  Compared to Humphry Slocombe the flavors at Salt and Straw tend to be more gourmet.  Think single origin olive oil ice cream, local coffee, and handmade cake with blackberries.  There are more traditional flavors like vanilla and chocolate.  You can also get ice cream shakes.  Pints are available to take home.  The ice cream was good, but shy of a super premium ice cream.  Super premium is a technical term that refers to a ice cream with high milk fat.  The good news is the flavors make up for the lack in a lower quality ice cream base.

Salt and Straw is an experience.  It would not be my everyday or weekly ice cream location.  Nor would I pay $11 for a pint when I can get a local super premium ice cream for half the price elsewhere.  

Come back in a few months after the hype wears off, or go in during the day on a week day.
author: Alan H.

description:
Salt & Straw is always a favorite! Super glad they opened two locations in SF. They always have such unique flavors, and the ice cream is creamy and smooth. 

I tried the sightglass coffee & single origin dandelion chocolate, and it was amazing. The flavor is so densely packed. I've also tried the sarsparilla and root beer float, which was interestingly awks. 

I came in November last year and got to try their interesting Thanksgiving flavors! The sweet potato casserole with maple pecan, buttered mashed potatoes and gravy, and persimmon and walnut stuffing were surprisingly good. I thought the salted caramel Thanksgiving turkey was a bit weird. I'll leave the turkey for dinner, not dessert. 

If you're overwhelmed with the number of choices and can't decide, the honey lavender is always a popular and top option! Lines can get long, but they come and go.
author: Tiffany H.

description:
There is always a line down the street at their other location on Fillmore, and for good reason. The Salt and Straw (originally based in Portland) has (in my humble opinion) the best ice cream ever. All of the flavors are very original, in combinations/creative flavors that I would never have thought of before. The ice cream is expensive ($5 for a single scoop, $7 for a double scoop, extra $1.25 for a waffle cone), but it is worth it. They also have a frequently rotating menu of new flavors. This month it was "Vegan New Year" so all of the flavors were vegan; in general, I don't like vegan ice cream, but I sampled the chocolate hazelnut fudge, and it was very good!

I got a double scoop of salted, malted, chocolate chip cookie dough and almond brittle with salted ganache on a waffle cone ($8.25). The almond brittle ice cream is to die for. It is packed full of sliced almonds and brittle, and every bite has so much delicious crunch to it. The chocolate chip cookie dough was also very good, with pockets of salted ice cream and cookie dough. Every bite was delicious. The waffle cones are also freshly made so you can smell them down the street, and they are very fresh and crunchy. Portion sizes are quite big.

I come back whenever I am in the area because this ice cream is absolutely addicting!
author: Amy C.

description:
Interesting...

I was grabbing dinner down the street and was looking for the address of the other ice cream place around the corner that starts with S and end with an Mitten, but was pleasantly surprised to find Salt & Straw in SF! 

The line was out the door, but it wasn't too long of a wait fortunately (maybe about 20-30 minutes?). Once it was our turn, I tried four flavors, and a lot of the flavors were really salty! I chose the Honey Lavender and the Roasted Strawberry. I loved both flavors which surprised me, because I usually don't like Strawberry ice cream and Honey Lavender is definitely a flavor people either love or hate. 

I got a waffle cup (tastes even better than it smells) with a single scoop split with two flavors (extra $.50). The Sightglass coffee & single origin dandelion was my next choice, but it just didn't stand out.

The flavor's are fun (some weird), the ice cream isn't cheap, but I'll be back! Next time, I'll grab a pint if I'm heading home right after.
author: Crystal K.

description:
After an ice cream pilgrimage through Portland last November, I was really happy to return to the Bay and find that there is not one, but TWO, Salt & Straw locations in SF.  I hope and pray that they'll open one in Oakland this year, but until then, I don't mind trekking into the city to get my honey lavender fix.  I've sampled most of the other flavors, even the monthly ones they churn out, but honey lavender remains my absolute favorite.  Some people think the lavender is too overwhelming, but the light purple color, floral smell and taste are just perfect to me.  That said, I usually get a solid scoop, but if I feel the need to change things up, I'll get a split scoop with either double fold vanilla or the chocolate gooey brownie.

I really like the community feel that Salt & Straw cultivates, too.  When this Hayes Valley location first opened up they had a photo backdrop area and a contest to possibly win a year of free ice cream.  

If you haven't already forked over your email, I highly encourage you to join their email list.  Not only will you be notified of the monthly flavors, but from time to time they'll send you promo codes.  At the end of 2017, I got a BOGO code which I used to get two split scoops... ah, ice cream heaven.  If you've been lucky enough to get paired up with a generous scooper, you'll know the joy of watching your split scoop become two baseball sized scoops in your cup/cone.  The cones, by the way, are pretty good - made fresh and really thick (watch your teeth!).
author: Iona C.

description:
For my first experience at Salt & Straw (SF) I opted to take full advantage of their December flavors and ABSOLUTELY fell in love with the gingerbread cookie dough flavor. It had just enough spice from the gingerbread and the dough pieces weren't too chunky (cause let's be real, ice cream is meant to be licked, not chewed). 

My second flavor was more chewing unfortunately. It was the chocolate peppermint flavor. On my test spoon, it seemed like chocolate ice cream infused with peppermint flavor which was awesome but the full version had giant minty pieces throughout which was a bit overwhelming in my opinion.

That said, Salt & Straw with its split scoop option is one of my favorite ice cream policy amongst the sea of ice cream vendors. I can't really consume a true double scoop portion of ice cream in one sitting so a split scoop definitely gives the best of both worlds in my opinion!
author: Elaine Y.

description:
This was my first time at Salt & Straw and it did not disappoint at all! I tried a few of the flavors before I ordered and it was hard to decide which ones to go with. I tried the honey and lavender, the Elvis one (I can't quite remember the name), the roasted strawberry tres leches, and the sarsaparilla and root beer float. I ended up going with the roasted strawberry and tres leches and a half scoop of the sarsaparilla and root beer float in a waffle cone. 

Both were extremely good. The ice cream servers were super nice and the line went very quickly even though it did look like a really long line when we first got there. I am definitely a fan and will more than likely be back. I LOVE that they have rotating flavors, I can't wait to see what flavors they come up with for the spring and summer. 

Also, this place is great to take a picky eater. They have vegan options and options for the lactose intolerants. :) This makes Salt & Straw even better in my opinion, I know I have some friends that are tough to have dessert with.
author: Stephanie A.

description:
Salt & Straw is one of my very favorite ice cream spots in the world, and I'm so glad they finally opened a more centrally located shop in San Francisco.

While the competition for frozen treats in the city is fierce, Salt & Straw is by far the most inventive. I probably visit at least 3x/month just so I can try each month's crazy new flavors. While I'm always curious about the new flavors, I wouldn't keep coming back if the flavors weren't well-executed. While I have my favorites from the classic menu (strawberry tres leches, honey lavender, salted malted cookie dough), I've fallen in love with so many of the seasonal flavors and always look forward to discovering new ones.

The wait can be long, but the line moves quickly, and the staff is always incredibly generous about allowing you to sample flavors.
author: Kelly R.

description:
I finally got a chance to try Salt & Straw and I thoroughly enjoyed it.  We found parking only a few blocks away, so I was feeling pretty fortunate, since it was a Saturday afternoon.  As I stood in line, it gave me an opportunity to look over the menu, since I saw several flavors that grabbed my interest.  Once I got to the counter, I sampled a couple of flavors and knew right away what I wanted.  I ordered a single split scoop, which allows you to get two non-full scoops, which I think is a great bonus.  Plus, we had just come from devouring a big lunch, so I wasn't as hungry as I normally would be.

I ordered the Sightglass Coffee & Single Origin Dandelion Chocolate.  I really like Sightglass espresso and it pairs really well with Dandelion Chocolate, so that was an easy choice.  For my other scoop, I opted for the Sarsaparilla & Dandelion Root Beer Float.  Notice, how I was able to get two scoops of ice cream with Dandelion Chocolate at the same time?  Yea, like that wasn't intentional.  The Sightglass Coffee had the perfect amount of coffee and chocolate flavor.  It wasn't watered-down like some coffee ice cream can be.  The Sarsaparilla wasn't overpowering and had just the right amount of Root Beer flavor.  

I love their originality and creativity of their ice cream flavors.  There were multiple flavors I was interested in, so I guess that means I'll just have to go back.  

The line moved fairly quickly and the staff was awesome.  They were friendly and helpful and let me sample whatever my heart desired.  We also found a couple of spots at the counter, so we were able to enjoy our treats without having to stand outside.
author: Lon H.

description:
I really love how the menu at salt and straw changes seasonally, and they have really interesting flavors and combinations. Of late, the PB&J with duck fat?? That was a little bizarre, and not up my ally . An interesting combination. Then there was something with Japanese whiskey. That was okay. I do love their strawberry and goat cheese - tastes like strawberry cheesecake. 

Try as many flavors as you want before you order! I appreciate that they use real spoons and wash them, versus disposable ones that can be bad for the environment. The tasting flavors is partially the reason why the lines can be so long. It's great that they opened up a second location in SF which also makes lines more manageable.
author: Vanessa K.

description:
Love this place. Wish there were more locations. If the shopping fee was not $25 I'd probably order more online.

Tip: get a split scoop to enjoy 2 flavors for $.50 more!
author: Nicole G.

description:
Black olive brittle and goat cheese!

Sweet brittle, with an earthy, salty, kalamata olive finish.  Creamy chevre, slightly tangy ice cream.  So delicious!
author: Sondra H.

description:
Deliciously interesting ice cream - that's their slogan & that sounds about right. :)

My bestie and I came here after dinner for some dessert. I asked her if she still had room for dessert in which she responded "of course!" haha.. When we arrived, there were just about 5 people in front of us. So not bad at all. But shortly after we were getting our scoops, so much people got in line! Where the hell did these people come from?! 

Anywho, I got the single scoop of honey lavendar and chocolate oooey brownie in a waffle cone while bestie also got honey lavendar and sea salt with caramel ribbon in a sugar cone. All was delish, but my fave would be definitely be the waffle cone + the chocolate oooey brownie ice cream. I think the honey lavendar ice cream is better else where. 

Overall yummy, and I would definitely return to try other flavors cause they do have some unique flavors. :)
author: Amy C.

description:
I have been to all the Salt & Straws in the Los Angeles area so I figured why not indulge in something I know to be great! We just finished a wonderful dinner with friends and before grabbing a night cap we grabbed delicious ice cream. 

Similar to all the other locations I have been to (alas, I have yet to be visit the original in Portland) they are very patient and helpful. They do not carry your typical ice cream flavors, but they are willing to let you try whichever one you want (literally, they will let you try them all) until you find the perfect scoop, or two, or three. 

The employees at this location were very cheerful. My go-to flavor is the honey lavender. A divisive flavor among my friends, some people love it and some do not care for it. I think it is the smoothest most comforting ice cream I have ever had the opportunity to indulge. 

The best part about Salt and Straw is their rotating flavors! Always an adventure and always an opportunity to taste all the flavors.

Enjoy!
author: Paul I.

description:
I've been here twice and I love it (minus the lines).

Salt & Straw has been on my radar ever since I traveled to Portland some time ago. When the boyfriend told me they opened a new location in the city, I was excited and he encouraged me to check it out even though we both knew the lines would be long.

The first time I came here, the line was out the door. However, it does move at an okay pace. I wish it moved faster, but the reason it doesn't is because the staff is welcoming and allows the customers to sample several different flavors.

I love that Salt & Straw offers innovative flavors, along with unique yet tasty seasonal flavors. For example, during the month of November they had some interesting flavors such as Turkey and Mashed Potatoes. To be honest I was scared to try them, but all the flavors worked really well and tasted great!

So far, I've tried their Roasted Strawberry Tres Leches, Peach Vinegar Cobbler with Toasted Nutmeg, Sightglass Coffee & Single Origin Dandelion Chocolate, Salted Honey Marshmallow & Walnuts, Food Runners Banana Bread Pudding, Spiced Goat Cheese & Pumpkin Pie, and their Gingerbread Cookie Dough. Out of those, my absolute favorite is the Sightglass Coffee & Single Origin Dandelion Chocolate and the Gingerbread Cookie Dough (seasonal)!

Overall, I'm happy that Salt & Straw has moved into the city. I love this particular location in Hayes Valley and extra kudos to the friendly and patient staff. The only cons I can think of is that parking is difficult at times and the long line.

Definitely worth the visit if you are in the city though!
author: Julia L.

description:
Typical new place strategy. We went in the early days of this store, ordered the sundae. It was good (although the icecream was too salty, but thats probably personal preference).
We went again today to get the same but with vanilla icecream instead of sea salt. We got it after 10 min wait, then it had 1 spoon of brownie! The brownie layer was less than 10mm, it was so thin we couldnt taste it. Not getting the Sundae from here again.
author: L Z.

description:
Great quality ice cream, but I'd probably stick to the classic flavors. They are very creative with their flavors for the holidays, but they taste so strange to me. I tried the sea salt with caramel ribbons and the peach vinegar cobbler with toasted nutmeg. Both were thick and creamy. I'd say they are a bit too sweet, though. The waffle cone is lightly sugary and is very crunchy.

The staff here are all very nice and friendly. You can ask them to give you a small sample spoon of any of the ice creams. It helps to have a sample before purchasing. I tried two of the Halloween flavors and called it quits, so I'm glad for the sampling. Otherwise, I'd have tossed my ice cream.

Interior is very clean. I like their decor, warm brown colors. There's only a small corner space to sit and eat your ice cream, so be prepared to either stand around inside or outside if you plan to stay.
author: Jasmine P.

description: Inventive flavors and on the sweet side. Store is wafting strongly of waffle cones which definitely whets appetite for dessert. Their ice-creams are very creamy and my favorite thus far is the Mt Tam cheese with Acme bread, such a wonderful combo. Not for the lactose intolerant for sure.
author: Shaw L.

description: This place was honestly the highlight of my recent trip to California! My cousin from SF took my boyfriend and I here, and it was love at first sample (seriously). It was great that the workers let you sample as many flavors as you want before you decide on what to get. There were a ton of unique flavors to choose from, but my favorite was the sea salt with caramel ribbons. I love any variation of salted caramel, so this was a dream come true; this flavor had just the right amount of salt complemented by the rich sweetness of the thick caramel ribbons. I got a split scoop (which is huge btw, definitely almost a double scoop) of that flavor as well as the salted malted chocolate cookie dough which I really liked too. Generous amount of cookie dough chunks, which was delicious. So glad a sweet tooth runs in my family and that I was introduced to this place :-)
author: Recel L.

description:
Not much I put in words about Salt & Straw of Hayes Valley; however, I did go to the other Salt & Straw of Fillmore and Sacramento St., where lines are still very long on my first visit (not as long as the longest line leading to Matcha Café Maiko of J-town shopping mall).  I had my ice cream and finished the whole cup before I move everywhere in Fillmore back then.

Here in Hayes Valley, I came to Salt & Straw for one unique purchase, Don Bugito's mealworms and coconut brittle.  By purchasing a packet of mealworms, we all made a good impact on the environment.  I'm glad workers of Salt & Straw are ahead of the game.
author: Jimmy C.

description:
Amazing, unique flavors! The smores one is amazing (it tastes like fire?!) and the honey lavendar literally tastes like my diffuser but in a good way. The line was out the door, but we were trying samples in about 15 minutes. Very patient workers as I tried a bunch of the flavors. 

They also have some pints to grab and go. I saw a nacho-flavored pint, actually. I give it 4 stars because the ice cream texture isn't as smooth and decadent as, like, Smitten. More icey. But still worth it!
author: Thu P.

description:
I love salt and straw! Their flavors are unique and very satisfying. I loved their roasted strawberry flavor. Supposedly it's one of sf's favorite flavors from salt and straw.  It was hard for me to choose between this one and the coffee flavored ice cream. 

There is always a line at this place, but I love trying all of their ice cream flavors. Another thing that I enjoy about salt and straw is that they tend to use ingredients that are local to the location. The salt and straw in Portland used tillamook cheese in one of their ice creams. This location used Dandelion chocolate which is a chocolate spot in sf. 

Definitely a great place to try if you're in the area. My boyfriend was able to find a street parking spot across the street from this place on a Friday night. Go to salt and straw!
author: Heather I.

description:
I've loved Salt & Straw since I got to try them in Portland.  I'm beyond ecstatic that they're now in California.  I just love the texture of their ice cream, and their flavors are very unique.

This location seems larger than the Fillmore location, and they have the same flavors available in both locations.  There's not a lot of seating inside, so it's best to take your treat to go if you can.

Service, unsurprisingly, is friendly and efficient.  And I don't ever feel rushed to choose a flavor quickly, even when their line is out the door.  Weekends and evenings are when the line is usually long.  I work nearby, so the line is pretty short during a weekday afternoon.  Though, tourist season hasn't started yet, so that may change.

Definitely check out their website for their monthly flavors.
author: Vira P.

description:
Ice cream is still as delicious as ever, but staff at this location need more training on how to scoop.

My first impression of this store was great. However, I'll unfortunately have to deduct a few stars after last weekend's visit. The staff at the Fillmore location are much friendlier and know how to handle crowds. This location is a bit hectic and the wait times are longer than average. 

My biggest gripe with this location is that last Saturday afternoon, the gal scooping the ice cream literally gave us the smallest scoops I've ever received from Salt & Straw. I've never had this issue in the past, as the servings are usually more than generous. 

My s/o said his single scoop was hollow on the inside. Also, my scoop of strawberry tres leches didn't even have any tres leches cake. 

Shouldn't there be a standard size for each scoop of ice cream? Why was she being so stingy -_-
author: Shirley H.

description: This is a whole 'nother dimension to fat-assedness: hot fudge brownie Sunday. This is harder to find in the city than you would expect. Gihardelli is the usual suspect but at $12 a pop I have to wait for a special occasion. Bi rite makes the best in SF, but they're usually busy or out of the way. Fenton's is great but too far. Enter salt and straw. With happy, youthful staff and eccentric flavors this should be everyone's go to spot in north-central SF. There was a flavor called goat cheese and olive, wow, Mediterranean ice cream flavors?!?! I'm trying that next time. This time I went for the lavender and s'mores. The lavender had a subtle smooth taste. The snore was light yet complex, the combination of the walnuts, Carmel and chocolate drizzle and whipped cream ensconced everything in a heavenly indulgent package ; come here to solve all your ice cream conundrums!!!
author: Johny B.

description: If you're looking for unusual (yet seasonal) flavor combinations that you might not find anywhere else, Salt & Straw is the place to come! On my visit in August, a whole section of the menu was dedicated to flavors that incorporated vegetables into the ice cream! I simply could not pick from all the different flavors they had--reading the long, thought-out descriptions on the full menu made everything just sound more enticing! In the end, I settled for the "Breakaway Matcha & Black Raspberry" which had a lovely combination of intense matcha with swirls of sweet/acidic berries, as well as the very unique "Carrot Cake Batter & Pralined Hazelnuts," an amazing combination of carrot cake, candied hazelnuts, and swirls of cheesecake frosting. Both these selections had a great balance of flavors and were some of the most unique I've had in a long time. One thing I loved especially about all the flavors I sampled was that all of them had amazingly delicious chunks! The prices aren't cheap, but Salt & Straw is definitely worth a visit for its unique flavors and super friendly service!
author: David K.

description:
I've never been to the super popular Salt & Straw in Oregon or their locations in LA before so I was beyond excited when I heard they were opening new shops in SF. I'm ALWAYS excited to try new ice cream shops and new flavors. 

This Salt and Straw location is located on Hayes Street in the Hayes Valley area of San Francisco. This is the downtown area of Hayes Valley where all the shops and restaurants are. It's convenient if you're in the area to do some shopping. There's plenty of street parking if you drive around for a while. 

I've been to the first location on Fillmore Street by Japantown a couple of times. I would say that this shop compared to that one is bigger. The space is wider so it doesn't feel as crowded. The setup of the queue is just as weird as the other shop though. If all the customers queue up from the left side of the entrance and all the customers who are done with their transactions are on the left side of that line, how easily can they leave if there's all these customers standing there blocking them from exiting? Wouldn't it just be better to have customers queue up outside from the right side instead? However the line does move pretty fast and they have a bunch of employees working inside to help expedite. 

They have a variety of interesting flavors on their menu and also seasonal ones which they switch every few months. When I was there, they had a bunch of Halloween flavors which sounded cool, but I wasn't that interesting in those. It's also great that they source their ingredients locally. I got myself a single scoop of Sightglass Coffee and Single Origin Dandelion Chocolate in a waffle cone. The flavor was creamy and decadent. The coffee flavor mixed with the chocolate was like eating an Iced Mocha if you can imagine. I would definitely get that flavor again. Also, the single scoop size is actually pretty large; imagine a tennis ball if you will. The kid's size is a little bigger than a golf ball. 

In San Francisco.....Mr & Mrs Miscellaneous, Coletta Gelato, and Humphrey Slocombe will still remain the top 3 in my heart. I feel Salt & Straw is a great addition to the city though. More options are always better! : )
author: Julie W.

description:
Delicious ice cream! What can I say more? They let you try all the different flavors, cause the naming is mind-blowing and it is sometimes hard to guess what might be hiding inside.
But one summer night in February we found ourselves down there at their Hayes location with a couple of friends. I have tried a couple of their flavorings, although I knew I was sold on the "salt" after trying it right away. $1.25 extra for a waffle cone - fine.
They don't have the restrooms which is a bummer!
author: Jakub S.

description: Love this ice cream shop. I always look forward to the inventive monthly flavors! This month's Chef Series' all stars in my book were the Tokyo PBJ and the Duck Crackling ice creams. Very decadent, but worth trying since the combos were so unique and bursted with nuances in flavor.
author: Camille E.

description: I was happy to see their locations in San Fran, I had been to their Portland location a while back and loooved their ice cream. Yes they have the same long lines, but they move fast. They have very unique flavor combos and quality ice cream. I was torn between a lot of options but went with almond brittle with salted ganache, divine!!!!!! Hey Salt and straw if you sell that salted ganache in a jar I would buy it!!!!! My advice, go stand on the line get their ice cream, you will be glad you did, I promise :)
author: Karen R.

description: I first tried this place when I visited portland back in 2014 and fell in love. I was so excited to see locations opening up in LA and SF. The classic flavors are always great, but I really love trying the featured flavors. They are hit or miss, but I'm always surprised by what they come up with. The line moves fast, so don't be too intimidated!
author: Erica C.

description:
Grand opening night, guess who came? MEEEEEEEEEEEE!!!

Love Salt & Straw ice cream so I had to get myself some of my favorites on a sugar cone:

1) Roasted Strawberry Tres Leches

2) Peach Vinegar Cobbler with Toasted Nutmeg

3) Teranga Baobab Juice & Coconut 


I know I say this A LOT, but I really love their Pear & Blue Cheese flavor in Portland. Can't wait to get some of that this weekend when I'm going to be in Portland. Yayer!! 


I hope you give this tasty ice cream place a try. Cheers!
author: Owie N.

description:
I had been looking for something sweet after lunch and I bumped into this place. I knew there was one on Hayes, but I was pleasantly surprised that this one had no line at 1pm in the afternoon. I had order the Warm brownie sundae with Roasted  Tres Leches strawberry ice cream. A lot of unique flavors Nice people who work here and nice clean store will
Make us come back for more flavors.
author: Robert R.

description:
Holy cow. Loved this place in Portland, and their new Hayes Valley location is awesome. Really great. Amazing ice cream, great service and a cool spot in the trendy section of Hayes.

Don't be intimidated. When you get up close to the front of the line, an ice cream consultant will come out and ask you what you want to taste. Taste away and make sure you get exactly what you're looking for. They walk you all the way through the process and make your cones for you.

Had the gooey chocolate brownie with salt topping on a waffle cone. Some of the best ice cream I've ever had.

Honey lavender was also a big hit..  also sea salt with caramel swirls. I mean. There's really nothing bad here.

We're big Bi-Rite fans...  and Smitten, but this is so much better. Run. Get ice cream. Now.
author: Bob K.

description:
After a 40 minute wait at their Fillmore location I had to give this one a shot... And 20 minutes later, I was much happier!

Same great flavors and same great taste, I'm a fan!!
author: Mandi W.

description:
The last time I went to Salt & Straw in Portland, I was forever scarred by a flight of floral ice creams that made me taste bark and leaves for hours afterwards. So when my friend suggested getting a flight this time around, I was understandably wary and refused to choose any flavors that I hadn't taste tested. 

Salt & Straw isn't afraid to experiment, which I really appreciate. Their Thanksgiving flavors are super fun - I tried mashed potatoes, sweet potato casserole, and goat cheese pumpkin pie. The mashed potatoes were really subtle, but when I tasted those potatoes, it was just too weird for me. Flashback to that scene in Charlie and the Chocolate Factory where Violet eats that gum that takes on the flavor of different dinners... No thanks. We went with the sweet potato, goat cheese pumpkin pie, strawberry tres leches, and honey lavender for our $11 flight, which I think is super worth because we got 4 fat scoops when a typical scoop is ~$5. 

I really enjoyed the goat cheese pumpkin pie because I love goat cheese, and I love pumpkin pie, and the combination was risky but so rewarding. There was a line on a Sunday evening but it moved quickly, and the servers were really patient with all the flavors I wanted to try.
